content.value: File system internals describe how Linux stores file information internally, while links allow multiple references to the same file.
content.example: Example: Two different filenames pointing to the same data.

content.value: Understanding file system internals helps users manage storage efficiently, troubleshoot file issues, and avoid accidental data loss. Links are commonly used in system directories, software installations, and shortcuts.
An inode is a data structure that stores information about a file except its name and actual data.
content.example: Example: File permissions and ownership are stored in the inode.

content.value: In Linux, filenames are not stored inside the file itself. Instead, filenames point to inodes. This allows multiple filenames (links) to reference the same inode.

content.description: Displays files along with their inode numbers.
